Title: A Landscape-Scale Study of Bumble Bee Foraging Range and Constancy, Using Harmonic radar
Which variables were measured?: nectar load, foraging time, trip duration outside nest
Result: Bees individually collected nectar loads weighing 110mg, 86mg and 129mg before transponder attachment and the same 3 bees collected nectar loads weighing 84 mg, 99 mg and 120 mg, respectively, with the transponder attached. A total of 22 foraging trips by five bees with transponders lasted on average 22.9 +- 5.6 min, while 27 trips made by the same bees before transponder attachment lasted on average 12.8 +- 2.5 min. Bees fitted with transponders, trips out the nest lasted on average 83.8 + 8.5 min. Trips for these bees before transponder attachment lasted an average of 56.5 + 4.4 min.
Remarks: They suspect that difference in foraging time is mainly due to handling time of the bees on individual flowers, and is not an impact of the wieght on the flight performance

Title: Electronic tags for the tracking of insects in flight: effect of weight on flight performance of adult Colorado potato beetles
Which variables were measured?: number of upward and downward flights, take-off angle, mortality (glue)
Found impact: yes, depending on ratio weight, no glue
Result: The propensity of Colorado potato beetles to takeoff and fly did not seem reduced by the addition of extra weight on their pronotum but their ability to fly upward was reduced.  (69 µN: almost no succesful take-offs. 41 µN: upward flights with a lower take off angle. 34 µN: a lot of upward flights with normal angles, but changed up/down flying ratio. 23 µN: did not change the up/down flight ration significantly from the untagged. None of the tags influenced the max height reached), Both Epoxy and Super glue were tested for toxicity, and showed no signs of increased mortality over a period of three weeks, compared to untagged beetles.
Remarks: They mention in their abstract 'It is estimated from our results that electronic tags should weigh no more than 23–33% of the potato beetle’s acceptable extra loading for', Later in their paper this acceptable extra loading is shown to be 2.4% of the beetle's own weight.

Title: Mating disruption in Agrotis segetum monitored by harmonic radar
Which variables were measured?: Behavioural steps to pheromone trap were scored (take flight, 3 orientation steps, entering trap). Proportions of these were compared
Result: No difference in overall ability to fly upwind in a pheromone plume in the wind tunnel was observed between tagged and untagged males

Title: Radio tagging reveals the roles of corpulence, experience and social information in ant decision making
Which variables were measured?: speed, sinuosity of paths, path length (with video analysis), corpulence
Result: The data do not indicate any effect of the RFID tagging on the speed, directness of path or corpulence.
Remarks: This impact assessment was elaborately described in the supplementary material of the paper.

Title: The potential of portable harmonic radar technology for the tracking of beneficial insects
Which variables were measured?: Number of upward and downward flights
Result: There was an obvious relation between the size of the extra weight and the total number of flights recorded. Except for the lighter extra weights, there was a tendency for a smaller total number of flights.
Remarks: However, the ability of many insects to carry heavy loads in flight must be distinguished from the ability of these insects to carry extra loads without negatively affecting flight performance. It is likely that maximum loads for flight all affect some aspects of flight performance.'

Title: Tracking butterfly flight paths across the landscape with harmonic radar
Which variables were measured?: Proportion of time spent flying/walking/resting for 30 min in flightroom
Result: For Inachis io there was no significant (F2,9=2.7, p>0.05) change to the butterfly's behavioural activities. Five per cent of time was spent flying with the transponder attached compared with 8% without, and respectively, 30% of time was spent walking, compared with 28% without the transponder.
Remarks: They also looked if behaviour was qualitatively normal

Title: Radiotelemetry reveals differences in individual movement patterns between outbreak and non-outbreak Mormon cricket populations
Which variables were measured?: walk time, speed, total distance, turn angle, turning rate, meander (with video analysis)
Result: Carrying a radio transmitter had no apparent effect on the short-term movement behaviour of either male or female Mormon crickets assayed in the lab.

Title: Effectiveness of Glues Used for Harmonic Radar Tag Attachment and Impact on Survival and Behavior of Three Insect Pests
Species (Order, Family): Conotrachelus nenuphar, Leptinotarsa decemlineata, Diabrotica virgifera, Diabrotica longicornis (Coleoptera, Curculionidae, Chrysomelidae, Chrysomelidae, Chrysomelidae)
What aspect was quantified?: Effect of glue for survival, behaviour and movement
Which variables were measured?: Effect of three types of glue on the survivorship, feeding activity, total distance, velocity, duration of movement, vertical dinstance travelled
Result: The cyanoacrylate glues were toxic for the Diabrotica sp., feeding activity and mobility were unaffected
Remarks: Which variables were tested depedented on which one of the three species was considered

Title: Harmonic Radar: Assessing the Impact of Tag Weight on Walking Activity of Colorado Potato Beetle, Plum Curculio, and Western Corn Rootworm
Species (Order, Family): Leptinotarsa decemlineata, Conotrachelus nenuphar, Diabrotica virgifera (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae, Curculionidae, Chrysomelidae)
Which variables were measured?: horizontal walking: distance, duration, walking speed, vertical walking: duration
Result: Response of walking insects to additional weight of tags is variable within and between species. The type and level of impact of a tag can vary according to the type of response of each sex or each species to different stimuli.

Title: Evaluation of Tag Entanglement as a Factor in Harmonic Radar Studies of Insect Dispersal
Species (Order, Family): Leptinotarsa decemlineata, Conotrachelus nenuphar, Diabrotica virgifera (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae, Curculionidae, Chrysomelidae)
Which variables were measured?: time for vertical climbing, horizontal walking comparing low and high likelihood of entanglement (bare ground and grass), comparing vertical and trailing tags for 2 species
Found impact: no vertical tags, yes trailing tags
Result: no difference for both kind of tags of Leptinotarsa decemlineata, Conootrachelus nenuphar was not affected by the vertical tag (no trailing tag tested), Diabrotica virgifera was affected by the trailing tag, impact of entanglement on bare ground and grass was minimal.
Remarks: They compared vertically attached tags and trailing tags and possibility of entanglement of the tag in vegetation

Title: Validation of harmonic radar tags to study movement of Chinese citrus fly
Which variables were measured?: Tag retention, surival, feeding duration, flight take-off, vertical movement
Result: 86% retained tag for at least 5 days, no effect on feeding duration, no significant mortality, vertical movement not hampered, take-off and flight performance not different.

Title: Space Use of Bumblebees (Bombus spp.) Revealed by Radio-Tracking
Species (Order, Family): Bombus hortorum, B. ruderatus, B. terrestris (Hymenoptera, Apidae)
Which variables were measured?: visitation rate, time on flowers
Result: Bumblebees with transmitters had significantly lower flower visitation rates (one-tailed t-test: t =11.7, df=213, p<0.001) and spent significantly more time foraging on individual flower heads (one-tailed t-test: t =11.2, df=18, p<0.001) than individuals without transmitters. We were unable to quantify whether this also means that foraging efficiency (i.e. nectar consumption per time) is reduced, or whether it simply reflects a difference in flower handling.
Remarks: Impact assessment was done on B. terrestris

Title: Effectiveness of Glues for Harmonic Radar Tag Attachment on Halyomorpha halys (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae) and Their Impact on Adult Survivorship and Mobility
Which variables were measured?: vertical walking ability, survival, flight distance, time duration from release to take-off, flight time, speed, direction
Result: There were no measurable negative effects of the tag pres- ence on the H. halys survivorship with any ofthe three glues tested. In addition, the presence ofradar tag did not adversely affect either walking or ßight behavior of this insect.

Title: Using Radio Telemetry to Assess Movement Patterns in a Giant Rhinoceros Beetle: Are There Differences Among Majors, Minors, and Females?
Which variables were measured?: speed
Result: No difference in flight speed before and after the radio tags were attached. (2.21+-0.33m/s after and before 2.16+-0.39m/s)

Title: Harmonic Radar Tagging for Tracking Movement of Nezara viridula (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae)
Which variables were measured?: walking distance, flying distance
Result: Walking distance in the laboratory and flying distance in the field variad significantly (p<0.05) between males and females, but not among treatments

Title: Radiotelemetry unravels movements of a walking insect species in heterogeneous environments
where was the tag attached: with fishing line hanging from the back
Which variables were measured?: time needed to cover fixed distance, with crop residues or not
Result: There was no significant difference for time to reach the edge of the wooden board between tagged and nontagged for both females and males
Remarks: It was qualitatively checked if they could enter and leave a pseudostem without entanglement.

Title: Effect of harmonic radar tagging on Lycorma delicatula (Hemiptera: Fulgoridae) nymphal mobility and survivorship
Which variables were measured?: horizontal walking distance, vertical climbing distance, jumping distance and time duration from release to jumping, survival
Result: No significant effects for all variables

Title: Potential of harmonic radar system for use on five economically important insects: Radar tag attachment on insects and its impact on flight capacity
Species (Order, Family): Riptortus pedestris, Lycorma delicatula, Ricania sp. (Hemiptera, Alydidae, Fulgoridae, Ricaniidae), Apis mellifera, Bombus terrestris (Hymenoptera, Apidae)
Which variables were measured?: time duration from release and take-off, success to make 30m sustained flight, flight direction
Result: Overall, radar tag attachment had different effects on flight behaviors of the five insect species. There was no measurable negative impact of the tag attachment on the proportion of individuals taking off within 3 min for R. pedestris, L. delicatula or B. terrestris (Fisher's exact test, P>0.6000). However, the proportion of individuals taking off was significantly decreased by the tag attachment for Ricania sp. (Fisher's exact test, P = 0.0001) and A. mellifera (Fisher's exact test, P= 0.0046).

Title: Evaluating effects of harmonic radar tag attachment on the survivorship and dispersal capacity of Riptortus pedestris (Hemiptera: Alydidae)
Which variables were measured?: survival, vertical distance climbed, duration between release and take-off
Result: No significant differences for all variables

Title: Recording the movement of adult vine weevil within strawberry crops using radio frequency identification tags
Which variables were measured?: horizontal speed, vertical speed, survival
Result: Mortalility depended on glue. Horizontal and vertical movement was slower when RFID was attached. However, under field conditions the speed of movement recorded was comparable to those previously reported for this species.

Title: Ontogeny of orientation flight in the honeybee revealed by harmonic radar
Which variables were measured?: foraging duration
Result: The duration of the orientatin flights of bees with and without transponders was not signficantly different (with transponders: mean +- se, 331.6+- 59.2s (n=29) versus without transponders: 340.1 +- 26.4 s (n=219), Wilcoxon test, P>0.05, n.s.)
